ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Christopher Kruse  Chris Kruse
Instructor: Christopher Kruse  Katherine Weber
Instructor: Christopher Kruse  Chris Kruse

Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was the absolute best! She was very encouraging and extremely generous with her time. There were multiple times she stayed in late or came in out of class hours to help different students. While remote sensing was very intimidating to me as a beginner, Natalie's nonjudgemental support as I was gathering my bearings made the course one of my favorites by the end of the year. She was very approachable, which made the topic more approachable as well as more enjoyable to study.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Katie Weber (FYI: this option was not available in the drop-down menu) my comments do not apply to Natalie Schultz
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  I work most closely to Katie who was the responsible of the Lab I belonged to.
Instructor: Varun Srinivasa Murthy  Varun

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Christopher Kruse  Chris is helpful most of the time although sometimes he would not be able to explain certain concepts clearly.
Instructor: Christopher Kruse  Chris was a huge help during lab periods and for my person project. Thanks so much!

Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  I have no complaints. Natalie's strengths include her wealth of knowledge that she generously offers with her approachability. She also has a gift for simplifying complex ideas and conceptualizing the class material in different ways.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Katie was always willing to help whenever necessary. She helped with troubleshooting issues as well as more conceptual ones.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Katie is very well-disposed instructor.

Instructor: Varun Srinivasa Murthy  Varun was extremely helpful and patient with our lab sessions and assignments. He was open to answer our questions outside of lab sessions and always went the extra mile to make sure that we understood the lab exercises correctly.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Pick a better book. There are much better texts out there.

I thought the first half of the semester was sort of a whirlwind. The midterm I thought wasn't really the best way to assess our understanding of a lot of material over short period of time. I think I would've preferred having two midterms was smaller amounts of info in the same time period. There really weren't a lot of examples to reinforce learning in the first half of the semester's material. It was just the problem sets which I thought was sort of a limited selection of objectives.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Lab exercise, project, field trip.
The lab was the best part. Larry is the best instructor--I learned so much from him.
Lab exercises Develop and finish a project Presentation
The lab exercises were really very beneficial and I thought flowed nicely with the lecture material. I also enjoyed some of the more applied labs like the force change detection lab.
The broad approach and overview during classes combined with the in depth assignments during the labs.
Practical knowledge about remote sensing.

The best aspects of this course was the subject matter itself. This course is extremely valuable and opened up an entire world of research possibilities. I though the first month of the course was excellent and an incredible introduction the the concepts.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The lecture was too theoretical and sometimes uninteresting.
Pick a different textbook--there are many others that provide a better contextualization of the material.

I think the beginning of the course needs to be assessed somehow perhaps with more ways to substantiate the lecture material. Or involve the TAs in making sure that we understand the concepts presented in the first half of the course. If we have so many TAs in the course it seems a waste not have them available for things like problem sets or midterm review. I also think it might be wise to make this course 4 credits simply because of the time required for the course on a weekly basis.
Emphasis on important concepts that are explained in the first sessions could be made in order to improve students' comprehension of its uses for later applications.

Generally, I enjoyed most aspects of this course. Sometimes I was hoping for a bit more from lecture in the second portion of the course and would have liked it to go into a bit more depth. At times it felt repetitive.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I thought the course lectures supplemented the lab exercises particularly well. However in some cases it was clear that the instructor had not examined the lab material very closely and perhaps could have beefed up the lecture to then allow us to better understand the lab rather than just giving us a basic background on the topic.
The lab, mid-term and classes are well-organized and well-timed.

I thought it was actually really good. Sometimes I thought there was too much focus placed on the labs though and would have rather been able to focus on my final project. Between lecturing about the lab and then actually doing the lab it seemed sometimes a bit repetitive.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Remote sensing is an important skill to understand if one wants to work further with many scientific topics. It's particularly useful I think to have an experience with the remote sensing in combination with GIS skills. I was fortunately able to use my project to supplement work that I was doing for my masters thesis and that's very valuable moving forward.

I am strongly interested in the use of remote sensing for the determination of change detection of water resources and water availability. Thus this course is very helpful to expand students' knowledge in this area.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To develop some remote sensing image processing skills

I wanted a better understanding of remote-sensing and the different products that are out there and how they can be manipulated and used. I took GIS an undergrad and so I wanted an opportunity to supplement my understanding of GIS with a slightly different perspective on data and data acquisition.
Critical to my masters research.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. Better than my expectation.
I would say that I learned a lot in this course but I don't know that the assessments really reinforce that knowledge. I think the lab exercises were potentially more productive in that regard.
Yes, totally.
Absolutely. Far and above.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I thought the lab group could have been a bit more cohesive. Most students didn't talk with each other or collaborate to figure out the labs. Seemed like the assumption was that we were all just required to be there at the same time, in which case I would have rather just come in on my own time. It would have been more valuable in the labs were set up in a way to foster teamwork.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Just know that this course is very time intensive. Following the midterm, the course isn't that difficult but just be prepared to spend a lot of time working on the labs in the project in the end. Also, if you struggle with some quantitative components be prepared to have your skills tested in the beginning of the semester with the problem sets and midterm. Make sure you stay on top of the problems that's in the midterm assignments and ask questions! The TA's are not very helpful in the beginning course material but can be very helpful with the lab exercises.

I would recommend this course for students that want to learn about remote sensing in its application for science (atmosphere, oceans, land, urban, forest). The course does not cover drones in an advanced level, rather there is only one introductory session.
Lot of work. Incredibly valuable.
